chapter.title: Network Usage by CSS
chapter.para: As a control system tool, CSS naturally performs a certain amount of network communication. For the most part, the CSS application that end users run acts as a network client, while tools like the Alarm Server will obviously also need to serve data.

sect1.title: Windows Firewall Warning
sect1.para: Even when running CSS as a client tool, you might run into the Windows Firewall warningFirewall Warning shown in .
The message appears because even a client tool like CSS does sometimes listen on network ports, i.e. act as a server. This usually happens for the following reasons:

itemizedlist.listitem: You configured logging to JMS (see and ). While connecting to JMS, CSS will also listen.
You opened the online help. Internally, this is implemented by CSS acting as a web server, and the help viewer is an ordinary web browser.

sect1.para: You can usually cancel that firewall warning, meaning Windows will block access from other computers on the network to your instance of CSS. Logging to JMS on another computer as well as local viewing of the online help will be unaffected.

sect1.title: Required Firewall Exceptions

itemizedlist.listitem: Archive Engines for access to their status web server

sect1.para: For details you will have to refer to the documentation of your firewall: Linux iptable, Windows firewall).
